long_description: Members of theÂ sysadminÂ fixed server role can perform any activity in the server
Members of theÂ serveradminÂ fixed server role can change server wide configuration options and shut down the server

Members of theÂ securityadminÂ fixed server role manage logins and their properties. They canÂ GRANT,Â DENY, andÂ REVOKEÂ server-level permissions. They can alsoÂ GRANT,Â DENY, andÂ REVOKEÂ database level permissions if they have access to a database. Additionally, they can reset passwords for SQL Server logins
Members of theÂ processadminÂ fixed server role can end processes that are running in an instance of SQL Server
Members of theÂ setupadminÂ fixed server role can add and remove linked servers by using Transact SQL statements. SysadminÂ membership is needed when using Management Studio
Members of theÂ bulkadminÂ fixed server role can run theÂ BULK INSERTÂ statement
TheÂ diskadminÂ fixed server role is used for managing disk files
Members of theÂ dbcreatorÂ fixed server role can create, alter, drop, and restore any database

Every SQL Server login belongs to theÂ publicÂ server role. When a server principal has not been granted or denied specific permissions on a securable object, the user inherits the permissions granted toÂ publicÂ on that object. Only assign public permissions on any object when you want the object to be available to all users. You can not change membership in public
